title: Ed Miliband defends Extinction Rebellion ‘crusties’ and backs mass tree planting
text:
To view this video please enable JavaScript, and consider upgrading to a web browser that supports HTML5 video

Ed Miliband has come out in support of Extinction Rebellion (XR), rubbishing comments damning activists as ‘uncooperative crusties’.

The former Labour leader said demonstrators had changed the political conversation by pushing environmental action onto the agenda – but expressed ‘sympathy’ with those who had been inconvenienced.

Speaking exclusively to Metro.co.uk, Mr Miliband backed the idea of planting more trees as a ‘natural solution’ to the climate crisis, as he became one of more than 400 MPs who collected a sapling from an XR initiative in Westminster.

Advertisement

Mr Miliband, a former shadow secretary of state for climate change, explained: ‘(This is) part of the natural solution to the climate emergency that we face. If we plant trees, they suck carbon dioxide in. They don’t deal with the whole problem but they are a contributor to the (solution).

‘I think it forces us to think about the land and the way we use it and of course about the broader issue.’

Mr Miliband talks to XR activist Matthew Shribman (Picture: Harrison Jones)

The ‘Reforest Earth’ initiative handed out trees to hundreds of MPs (Picture: Harrison Jones)

Activists say planting one million trees would only counteract the last five minutes of global emissions – and are urging governments to plant more.

Attorney General Geoffrey Cox, Green Party MP Caroline Lucas and former Liberal Democrat leaders Vince Cable and Tim Farron all collected trees, as well as representatives for Prime Minister Boris Johnson and Labour leader Jeremy Corbyn.

But in a thinly veiled swipe at Mr Johnson, following his comments about XR protesters, Mr Miliband continued: ‘I am not in the uncooperative crusties’ camp, I think politicians who are failing to deal with the climate emergency should be careful about what they say. These are decent people who are trying to draw attention to this.’

(XR) protesters, who have camped out in Westminster, are urging the government to ‘tell the truth’ on the climate crisis (Picture: PA Wire)

Mr Johnson’s father Stanley said earlier this week that he is proud to be an ‘uncooperative crusty’.

Advertisement

Advertisement

Protesters from XR have caused major disruption in London since Monday, as part of a global plan to draw attention to global heating through a fortnight of action.

Mr Miliband conceded that many did not agree with the tactics but said ‘most people recognise the aims’ as being important.

Bus driver praised after taking detour to help 'sobbing' little girl get home

He appeared to back the group’s methods, explaining: ‘I think it is incredibly important it is nonviolent. There is a tradition of civil disobedience in this country.

‘XR hopefully are being careful about who they disrupt and how they cause disruption. It is not all the time, it has been every so often. Of course, for those people whose lives and work have been disrupted I am incredibly sympathetic but I think (XR) are trying to draw attention to an incredibly important issue.’

Though the group have faced criticism, the ‘Reforest Earth’ initiative of distributing trees has won praise, particularly from MPs.

One organiser, XR activist and scientist Matthew Shribman, said: ‘The government need to be talking about billions of trees.

‘We have been getting literally hundreds of MPs coming down to collect their trees (and) having really good conversations with everyone about how we need to massively accelerate our tree planting and radically reforest this country.’

Advertisement

Scientists suggest planting roughly a trillion trees would absorb the last 10 years’ worth of global emissions, while the UK government has committed to plant 11 million new trees by 2022 – roughly a 0.5% increase in coverage.

Mr Miliband said the combination of XR and the school climate strikes had ‘changed the conversation’ and forced ‘the climate emergency into the political conversation’ at a time when Brexit seems to be the only topic attracting interest.

He urged politicians to ‘do more… a lot more, with much greater urgency and (on a) much greater scale’ over climate.

description: Former Labour leader says Reforest Earth initiative is part of 'natural solution' to climate change and condemns Boris Johnson's comments.
